diff_hunk:
@@ -72,33 +72,31 @@ PyObject * THSPTensor_(size)(PyObject *self, PyObject *args, PyObject *kwargs)
 
 [[
   name: indices
-  defined_if: "!IS_CUDA"
   sparse: yes

+  return: THIndexTensor*
   arguments:
   - THSTensor* self
 ]]
 
 [[

-  defined_if: "IS_CUDA"
+  name: values
   sparse: yes
-  return: THCudaLongTensor*
+  return: THTensor*
   arguments:
   - THSTensor* self
 ]]
 
-
 [[
-  name: values
+  name: contiguous
   sparse: yes
-  return: THTensor*
+  return: argument 0
   arguments:
   - THSTensor* self

-  name: contiguous
+  name: markContiguous
+  python_name: mark_contiguous
body: I forgot to clean this up. The idea is to use it when you know your tensor is already contiguous (e.g. if you built the tensor after building the indices/values with numpy). I needed it when `contiguous` was still using insertion sort. It might still be useful now because `contiguous` is a bit expensive even with faster sorting. However it's a dangerous API so I'll remove it until a clear use-case comes up.

I needed it when contiguous was still using insertion sort. It might still be useful now because contiguous is a bit expensive even with faster sorting. However it's a dangerous API so I'll remove it until a clear use-case comes up.
body_text: I forgot to clean this up. The idea is to use it when you know your tensor is already contiguous (e.g. if you built the tensor after building the indices/values with numpy). I needed it when contiguous was still using insertion sort. It might still be useful now because contiguous is a bit expensive even with faster sorting. However it's a dangerous API so I'll remove it until a clear use-case comes up.
